description: From Middle English ded, deed, from Old English dēad, from Proto-West Germanic *daud, from Proto-Germanic *daudaz.
Compare West Frisian dead, dea, Dutch dood, German tot, Danish, Norwegian død, Norwegian Nynorsk daud.

adjectives.description: dead (not generally comparable, comparative deader, superlative deadest)

entries.meaning: (usually not comparable) No longer living; (usually only when referring to people) deceased#Adjective. (Also used as a noun.)
examples: Timothy Leary's dead. / No, no no no, he's outside, looking in.

entries.meaning: (usually not comparable) Devoid of living things; barren.
examples: a dead planet

entries.meaning: (hyperbolic) Figuratively, not alive; lacking life.
(of another person) So hated or offensive as to be absolutely shunned, ignored or ostracized.
examples: He is dead to me.

entries.meaning: Doomed; marked for death; as good as dead (literally or as a hyperbole).
examples: "You come back here this instant! Oh, you're dead, mister!"

entries.meaning: Without emotion; impassive.
examples: She stood with dead face and limp arms, unresponsive to my plea.

entries.meaning: Stationary; static; immobile or immovable.
examples: the dead load on the floor
a dead lift

entries.meaning: Without interest to one of the senses; dull; flat.
examples: dead air
a dead glass of soda.

entries.meaning: Unproductive; fallow.
examples: dead time
dead fields

entries.meaning: (of a place) Lacking usual activity; unexpectedly quiet or empty of people.
examples: Antonyms: alive, bustling, busy, crowded, hopping, lively, noisy
For a Friday night, it's really dead in this restaurant.

entries.meaning: (not comparable, of a machine, device, or electrical circuit) Completely inactive; currently without power; without a signal; not live.
examples: OK, the circuit's dead. Go ahead and cut the wire.
Now that the motor's dead you can reach in and extract the spark plugs.

entries.meaning: (of a battery) Unable to emit power, being discharged (flat) or faulty.
(not comparable) Broken or inoperable.
examples: That monitor is dead; don’t bother hooking it up.

entries.meaning: (not comparable) No longer used or required.
examples: There are several dead laws still on the books regulating where horses may be hitched.
Is this beer glass dead?

entries.meaning: (engineering) Intentionally designed so as not to impart motion or power.
examples: the dead spindle of a lathe
A dead axle, also called a lazy axle, is not part of the drivetrain, but is instead free-rotating.

entries.meaning: (not comparable, sports) Not in play.
examples: Once the ball crosses the foul line, it's dead.

entries.meaning: (not comparable, golf, of a golf ball) Lying so near the hole that the player is certain to hole it in the next stroke.
(not comparable, baseball, slang, 1800s) Tagged out.
(not comparable) Full and complete (usually applied to nouns involving lack of motion, sound, activity, or other signs of life).
examples: dead stop
dead sleep
dead giveaway
dead silence

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Exact; on the dot.
examples: dead center
dead aim
a dead eye
a dead level

entries.meaning: Experiencing pins and needles (paresthesia).
examples: After sitting on my hands for a while, my arms became dead.

entries.meaning: (acoustics) Constructed so as not to reflect or transmit sound; soundless; anechoic.
examples: a dead floor

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Bringing death; deadly.
(law) Cut off from the rights of a citizen; deprived of the power of enjoying the rights of property.
examples: A person who is banished or who becomes a monk is civilly dead.

entries.meaning: (rare, especially religion, often with "to") Indifferent to; having no obligation toward; no longer subject to or ruled by (sin, guilt, pleasure, etc).
examples: He was dead to the law. Whatever account others might make of it, yet, for his part, he was dead to it.  […]  But though he was thus dead to the law, yet he  […]  was far from thinking himself discharged from his duty to God' on the contrary, he was dead to the law, that he might live unto God.

entries.meaning: (degree, informal, colloquial) Exactly.
examples: dead right; dead level; dead flat; dead straight; dead left
He hit the target dead in the centre.

entries.meaning: (degree, informal, colloquial) Very, absolutely, extremely.
examples: dead wrong; dead set; dead serious; dead drunk; dead broke; dead earnest; dead certain; dead slow; dead sure; dead simple; dead honest; dead accurate; dead easy; dead scared; dead solid; dead black; dead white; dead empty

entries.meaning: Suddenly and completely.
examples: He stopped dead.

entries.meaning: (informal) As if dead.
examples: dead tired; dead quiet; dead asleep; dead pale; dead cold; dead still

entries.meaning: (often with "the") Time when coldness, darkness, or stillness is most intense.
examples: The dead of night. The dead of winter.

entries.meaning: (UK) (usually in the plural) Sterile mining waste, often present as many large rocks stacked inside the workings.
(bodybuilding, colloquial) Clipping of deadlift.

verbs.description: dead (third-person singular simple present deads, present participle deading, simple past and past participle deaded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To prevent by disabling; stop.
examples: “What a man should do, when finds his natural impotency dead him in spiritual works”

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make dead; to deaden; to deprive of life, force, or vigour.
(UK, US, transitive, slang) To kill.
